entry.title: Add Indicator Counter on Launchpad Application Tiles
entry.content:
Add Indicator Counter on Launchpad Application Tiles

 

 

 

Introduction
Sometimes you want your Launchpad tile to do more than just open the app â€” you want it to give quick, real-time information at a glance. For example, showing the number of pending requests, open orders, or alerts right on the tile. This is where the indicator counter comes in. In this guide, weâ€™ll walk through how to pull data from your service and display it as a counter on the tile in SAP Launchpad.

Pre-requisite

  • You must have SAP Work Zone (or Launchpad Service) subscribed in your BTP cockpit.
  • Your application should already be deployed and available on the Launchpad.

Steps

  1. Find your entity for counting
    Open your application in the browser, go to Developer Tools â†’ Network tab, and click on your service metadata file. This lists all entities available in your OData service.
    • Pick the entity you want to count.
    • Append /$count to its URL to get just the number of records instead of the full dataset.
    • You can also add filters.

  

             

 

          

/odata/v2/trm/TRMHeader/$count

2.Update manifest.json
In your applicationâ€™s manifest.json, after the dataSources section under sap.app, add the crossNavigation configuration:

"crossNavigation": {

  "inbounds": {

    "trade_module-display": {

      "semanticObject": "tilecounter",

      "icon": "sap-icon://inspection",

      "action": "display",

      "title": "Tile Counter",

      "subTitle": "No. of Request",

      "signature": {

        "parameters": {},

        "additionalParameters": "allowed"

      },

      "indicatorDataSource": {

        "dataSource": "mainService", // Must match the name of your defined dataSource

        "refresh": 6000,             // Auto-refresh every 6 seconds

        "path": "TRMHeader/$count"   // Path to fetch count data

      }

    }

  }

}
{
  "dataSources": {
    "mainService": {
      "uri": "/odata/v2/trm/",
      "type": "OData",
      "settings": {
        "annotations": [],
        "localUri": "localService/mainService/metadata.xml",
        "odataVersion": "2.0"
      }
    }
  },
  "crossNavigation": {
    "inbounds": {
      "trade_module-display": {
        "semanticObject": "trade_module", // data source should be same  as mentioned at line 03
        "icon": "sap-icon://inspection",
        "action": "display",
        "title": "Tile Counter",
        "subTitle": "No. of Request",
        "signature": {
          "parameters": {},
          "additionalParameters": "allowed"
        },
        "indicatorDataSource": {
          "dataSource": "mainService",
          "refresh": 6000,
          "path": "TRMHeader/$count"
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

 

Explanation of each line:

  • crossNavigation â€“ Tells Launchpad how this tile should behave and what data to show.
  • inbounds â€“ Defines the entry point configuration for your tile.
  • trade_module-display â€“ The unique inbound key (can be any meaningful name).
  • semanticObject â€“ Used for navigation in Launchpad; should align with your routing setup.
  • action â€“ The action to trigger when the tile is clicked.
  • title â€“ Main title text of the tile.
  • subTitle â€“ Subtitle under the main title.
  • indicatorDataSource â€“ This is where the magic happens:
    • dataSource â€“ Name of the service defined in dataSources. Must match exactly.
    • refresh â€“ How often to fetch new count data (in milliseconds).
    • path â€“ OData endpoint for the count. This is what the tile uses to update its counter.
  1. Deploy and Check
    After youâ€™ve updated and saved the manifest, build and redeploy your app. Open the Launchpad and you should now see the counter appearing and updating automatically.

      

            

 

Conclusion
Adding a counter to a Launchpad tile gives users instant insight without having to open the app. Itâ€™s a small change, but it can make navigation more efficient and the overall user experience more intuitive.

entry.title: PO Price Adoption Option in Purchase Requisition (Price get copied from PR to PO)
entry.content:
Configurations to activate PO Price Adoption from PR to PO when creating a PO with reference to PR. 

Step 1: We can check the Purchase Requisition screen in ME51N or ME52N to verify if PO Price Adoption is activated or not.

Step 2: Go to the configuration settings with the path below.
SAP IMG -> Materials Management -> Purchasing -> Purchase Requisition -> Define Configurations based on Purchase Requisition Origin

Step 3: Add New Entry and select which type of procurement (Self-Serve Procurement or Professional Procurement).
Select the right type of procurement below and activate "PO price Adoption". Below, I am selecting the "Professional Procurement" option and save this configuration. 

Then do the same for Self-service procurement in case you need this option too.
Then click back, and here we can see both options as below, and still we can make changes in case we want to select or deselect these options any time in future. 

Step 4: Test the option in the PR screen. 
Run ME51N or ME52N 

Select the right option and check in the PO Price while creating the PO with reference to PR, the system will bring the Price as per the options.
The available options are:
- Do not adopt â€“ PO will determine price independently (no carry-over).
- As gross price â€“ the gross price (including taxes, etc.) from the PR is adopted in the PO.
- As net price â€“ the net price (excluding taxes and other elements) from the PR is adopted in the PO.

Thanks 
Santosh G

entry.title: Converting FSV (Financial Statement Version) into a Flattened Structure using Python
entry.content:
Introduction

The Financial Statement Version (FSV) is one of the most critical structures in SAP for representing how financial data rolls up across accounts and reporting nodes. This article walks through how to use Python within Datasphere Dataflows to flatten the hierarchical FSV structure into a simple, analysis-ready table.

Use case A: Often flattened structures are required by a downstream system (e.g. Onestream, Snowflake or Azure) from SAP Datasphere.

Use case B: Reporting requirements on flattened structure in SAC (SAP Analytics Cloud) stories.   

*Figure : Example of a Financial Statement Version hierarchy with multiple reporting levels.* 

Python Transform

The FSV in SAP stores hierarchical information - each node represents a reporting group, which may have sub-nodes or leaf nodes pointing to G/L accounts.

Source Data:

Using a Python Transform node inside a Datasphere Dataflow, we can achieve this through a recursive traversal. The logic builds two key lookup dictionaries:

  • One mapping each parent node to its children
  • Another mapping each node ID to its node name

Then, a recursive build_paths() function walks through the hierarchy using Depth-First Search (DFS) - visiting each node, building its full path (e.g., Financial Statement Version > Assets > Current Assets), and recording its level details (LEVEL1, LEVEL2, etc.).

# Ensure no missing values in parent IDs
    data["PARENT_ID"] = data["PARENT_ID"].fillna("ROOT")

    # Build lookup dictionary: parent â†’ children
    children_map = data.groupby("PARENT_ID")["NODE_ID"].apply(list).to_dict()
    names_map = data.set_index("NODE_ID")["NODE_NAME"].to_dict()

    # Recursive function to build paths
    def build_paths(node, path):
        name = names_map.get(node, "")
        current_path = path + [name] if name else path
        results = [{"NODE_ID": node,
                    "NODE_NAME": name,
                    "FULL_PATH": " > ".join(current_path),
                    "LEVEL1": current_path[0] if len(current_path) > 0 else None,
                    "LEVEL2": current_path[1] if len(current_path) > 1 else None,
                    "LEVEL3": current_path[2] if len(current_path) > 2 else None,
                    "LEVEL4": current_path[3] if len(current_path) > 3 else None,
                    "LEVEL5": current_path[4] if len(current_path) > 4 else None,
                    "LEVEL6": current_path[5] if len(current_path) > 5 else None,
                    "LEVEL7": current_path[6] if len(current_path) > 6 else None,
                    "LEVEL8": current_path[7] if len(current_path) > 7 else None}]
        for child in children_map.get(node, []):
            results.extend(build_paths(child, current_path))
        return results

    # Start from ROOT (or null parent)
    flattened = []
    for root in children_map.get("ROOT", []):
        flattened.extend(build_paths(root, []))

    # Convert back to DataFrame
    data = pd.DataFrame(flattened)

    return data


The final output is a flat table showing node ID, name, full path, and level columns - ready for SAC visualizations or direct joins with GL balances.

 

 

Conclusion 

This approach ensures that the FSV - a cornerstone of SAP Financials remains a powerful, adaptable asset for unified financial reporting and planning.  This method simplifies downstream modelling and Python gives developers precise control over custom FSV structures or hybrid hierarchies that span SAP and non-SAP sources.

 

(To know more about FSV- refer the SAP learning journey)

entry.title: From SAP Datasphere to a Local LLM (Llama 3.1) â€” Hands-On Tutorial
entry.content:
Introduction 

This post documents a small, reproducible pattern for bringing SAP Datasphere data to a local large language model (LLM) for lightweight analysis. The goal is simple: keep modeling and governance in Datasphere, pull a view into a Jupyter notebook with pandas, and let a local LLM produce machine-readable JSON that you can filter, join, or visualize. The prototype runs on a CPU-only laptop so anyone can follow along without special hardware.

What this is:
- A step-by-step walkthrough that uses hdbcli to query a Datasphere view and Transformers to run Meta Llama 3.1 locally.
- A row-by-row prompt pattern that returns compact JSON (total, average, flags) you can plug back into your DataFrame. A row-by-row prompt pattern that returns compact JSON (total, average, flags) you can plug back into your DataFrame.
- A row-by-row prompt pattern that returns compact JSON (total, average, flags) you can plug back into your DataFrame.

What this is not:
- A benchmarking or performance guide. CPU runs are slow but convenient for learning.
- A recommendation to hard-code credentials. The POC mirrors the original notebook for clarity; use environment variables or a vault in real projects.A recommendation to hard-code credentials. The POC mirrors the original notebook for clarity; use environment variables or a vault in real projects.
- A pattern for sending sensitive data to external endpoints. Use test or masked data if you move past local inference. A pattern for sending sensitive data to external endpoints. Use test or masked data if you move past local inference.

What you will build:

A compact flow: SAP Datasphere View -> Python/Jupyter (hdbcli + pandas) -> row-level prompt -> Local LLM (Transformers) -> JSON back to DataFrame. The same prompts can be pointed to managed inference later for production.

Prerequisites

1. SAP Datasphere space with permission to create a Database User and a SQL View
2. Python 3.10+ with Jupyter
3. Libraries: pandas, hdbcli, transformers, torch, accelerate, ipython
4. Hugging Face account + access token (accept access for the Llama 3.1 model)

Security note: The POC code below uses inline credentials to mirror the original run. In real work, put secrets in environment variables or a vault and keep TLS validation enabled.

Part A â€” SAP Datasphere

A1. Enable database access for the space

1. Open SAP Datasphere -> Spaces -> select your space.
2. Go to Database Access and confirm SQL access is enabled for the space 

A2. Create a Database User

1. Database Access -> Database Users -> Create.Database Access -> Database Users -> Create.
2. Grant only read privileges/necessary privileges to the schema/view you will query.
3. Copy the SQL Endpoint (host) and port 443 for Python connectivity. Make sure you copy password and host details and store it in a safe place. 

A3. Create a demo view with a few rows

Create a SQL View (or graphical view). Here we have taken  "ACN_DWC"."DemoView_SETHIR_PY" with columns:
Stud_ID, Stud_Fname, Stud_Lname, Stud_DOB, Maths, Physics, Chemistry, Total, Stud_Addr, Stud_Faname for the demo.
Make sure the view is exposed for Consumption.
Optional seed SQL you can adapt:

SELECT * FROM (
  SELECT 101 AS Stud_ID, 'Arjun'     AS Stud_Fname, 'Singh'    AS Stud_Lname, DATE'2012-04-06' AS Stud_DOB,
         80 AS Maths, 75 AS Physics, 80 AS Chemistry, 235 AS Total, 'Chandigarh' AS Stud_Addr, 'Sukhdev' AS Stud_Faname
  UNION ALL
  SELECT 102, 'Harpreet', 'Kaur',  DATE'2010-09-08', 85, 78, 85, 248, 'Ludhiana',  'Gurinder'
  UNION ALL
  SELECT 103, 'Gursimran','Gill',  DATE'2011-07-09', 95, 85, 90, 270, 'Amritsar',  'Balwinder'
  UNION ALL
  SELECT 104, 'Manpreet', 'Sidhu', DATE'2014-01-01', 90, 85, 95, 270, 'Patiala',   'Harjit'
  UNION ALL
  SELECT 105, 'Jasleen',  'Dhillon',DATE'2012-03-02', 89, 90, 75, 254, 'Jalandhar', 'Paramjit'
) AS t;
SELECT * FROM (
  SELECT 101 AS Stud_ID, 'Arjun'     AS Stud_Fname, 'Singh'    AS Stud_Lname, DATE'2012-04-06' AS Stud_DOB,
         80 AS Maths, 75 AS Physics, 80 AS Chemistry, 235 AS Total, 'Chandigarh' AS Stud_Addr, 'Sukhdev' AS Stud_Faname
  UNION ALL
  SELECT 102, 'Harpreet', 'Kaur',  DATE'2010-09-08', 85, 78, 85, 248, 'Ludhiana',  'Gurinder'
  UNION ALL
  SELECT 103, 'Gursimran','Gill',  DATE'2011-07-09', 95, 85, 90, 270, 'Amritsar',  'Balwinder'
  UNION ALL
  SELECT 104, 'Manpreet', 'Sidhu', DATE'2014-01-01', 90, 85, 95, 270, 'Patiala',   'Harjit'
  UNION ALL
  SELECT 105, 'Jasleen',  'Dhillon',DATE'2012-03-02', 89, 90, 75, 254, 'Jalandhar', 'Paramjit'
) AS t;

 SAP Datasphere DB user : 
SAP Datasphere DB user screen

Demo View :

Part B â€” Local environment (quick path)

1. Create a project folder and venvCreate a project folder and venv

mkdir datasphere-local-llm && cd datasphere-local-llm
python -m venv .venv
# Windows: .venv\Scripts\activate
# macOS/Linux:
source .venv/bin/activate

2. Install requirements 

pip install hdbcli
pip install sqlalchemy
pip install sqlalchemy-hana
pip install pandas
pip install hdbcli
pip install transformers torch accelerate
pip install ipython

 3. Launch Jupyter

jupyter notebook

Part C â€” Original POC notebook

1. Open a new notebook and write the code.

# --- Imports and setup (original)
import pandas as pd
from hdbcli import dbapi
import warnings
from transformers import pipeline
from IPython.display import display
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

# --- Inline credentials (POC-style; replace with environment variables for real use)
db_user = 'ACN_DWC#SETHIR_DB'
db_password = 'secret'
db_host = 'secret'
db_port = 443
db_schema = 'ACN_DWC'


connection = dbapi.connect(
    address = db_host,
    port = db_port,
    user = db_user,
    password = db_password,
    encrypt = True,
    sslValidCertificate = False   # POC-only convenience; prefer True in real use
)
print("Connected to SAP Datasphere - confirmation")

2. If you see the output - "Connected to SAP Datasphere - confirmation" -- this implies you are on right track.

# --- Query the view
view_name = 'DemoView_SETHIR_PY'
sql_query = f'SELECT * FROM "{db_schema}"."{view_name}"'
print(f"Executing query: {sql_query}")

cursor = connection.cursor()
cursor.execute(sql_query)
rows = cursor.fetchall()
columns = [desc[0] for desc in cursor.description]

df = pd.DataFrame(rows, columns=columns)
display(df.head())

3. At this point, you should see the outcome of the view that you have. The last statement is used for displaying the data in the form of pandas dataFrame.

4. Now we need to prepare our data , so that the LLM can process it. This can be done by converting our data in the form of string format.

# ==============================================================================
#Prepare Data and Interact with OpenLLM
# ==============================================================================

# Convert DataFrame to a string
data_as_string = df.to_string(index=False)
print("\n--- Data Prepared for LLM ---")
print("The DataFrame has been converted to the following string format:")
print(data_as_string[:300] + "\n...")  # snippet preview

5. Prepare data pipeline :

# --- LLM imports
import os
import torch
import json
from transformers import AutoTokenizer, AutoModelForCausalLM, BitsAndBytesConfig, pipeline

# --- LLM Configuration
MODEL_ID = "meta-llama/Meta-Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct"

def load_llama_pipeline():
    """
    Loads the quantized Llama 3 model, tokenizer, and the text-generation pipeline.
    """
    print("\n--- Loading Llama 3 Model ---")
    hf_token = "secret"  # replace with your HF token; accept model access first

    quantization_config = BitsAndBytesConfig(
        load_in_4bit=True,
        bnb_4bit_quant_type="nf4",
        bnb_4bit_compute_dtype=torch.bfloat16
    )

    tokenizer = AutoTokenizer.from_pretrained(MODEL_ID, token=hf_token)
    model = AutoModelForCausalLM.from_pretrained(
        MODEL_ID,
        token=hf_token,
        quantization_config=quantization_config,
        torch_dtype=torch.bfloat16,
        device_map="auto",
    )

    print("Model loaded. Creating text generation pipeline...")
    return pipeline(
        "text-generation",
        model=model,
        tokenizer=tokenizer,
    )

6. Build the prompt for the LLM model :

# --- Prompt builder 
def build_student_analysis_prompt(tokenizer, student_data: pd.Series) -> str:
    """
    Builds a structured prompt for Llama 3 to analyze student marks.
    """
    input_text = (
        f"Student {student_data['Stud_Fname']} {student_data['Stud_Lname']} "
        f"(ID: {student_data['Stud_ID']}) scored {student_data['Maths']} in Maths, "
        f"{student_data['Physics']} in Physics, and {student_data['Chemistry']} in Chemistry."
    )

    messages = [
        {
            "role": "system",
            "content": (
                "You analyze one student's marks and return ONLY a valid JSON object. "
                "Output must start with '{' and end with '}'. No commentary, no markdown, no backticks.\n\n"
                "Schema (keys and types MUST match exactly):\n"
                "{\n"
                '  "total_marks": <int>,\n'
                '  "average_percentage": <float>,\n'
                '  "is_top_performer": <boolean>\n'
                "}\n\n"
                "Rules:\n"
                "1) total_marks = Maths + Physics + Chemistry (each out of 100).\n"
                "2) average_percentage = total_marks / 3.\n"
                "3) Round average_percentage to TWO decimals.\n"
                "4) is_top_performer = true if average_percentage > 80.0; else false.\n"
                "5) Use lowercase true/false for booleans.\n"
                "6) Do not include extra keys. Do not include trailing commas.\n"
                "7) Return JSON only."
            )
        },
        {
            "role": "user",
            "content": input_text
        }
    ]
    return tokenizer.apply_chat_template(messages, tokenize=False, add_generation_prompt=True)

7. Do the analysis : 

# --- Row-by-row analysis
def analyze_student_data(df, text_pipeline):
    """
    Analyzes the student DataFrame row by row using the LLM pipeline.
    """
    print("\n--- Starting Student Performance Analysis with Llama 3 ---")
    results = []
    for index, row in df.iterrows():
        print(f"\nAnalyzing student ID: {row['Stud_ID']}...")

        prompt = build_student_analysis_prompt(text_pipeline.tokenizer, row)

        raw_output = text_pipeline(
            prompt,
            max_new_tokens=128,
            do_sample=False,  # deterministic
            temperature=None,
            top_p=None,
        )[0]['generated_text']

        json_response_str = raw_output[len(prompt):].strip()
        try:
            analysis_result = json.loads(json_response_str)
            results.append(analysis_result)
            print("Analysis successful.")
        except json.JSONDecodeError:
            print(f"  > Failed to decode JSON from model output.")
            print(f"  > Raw model output: {json_response_str}")
            results.append({"error": "Invalid JSON output", "raw_output": json_response_str})

    print("\n--- Analysis Complete ---")
    return pd.DataFrame(results)

# --- Main
if __name__ == "__main__":
    if df is not None and not df.empty:
        try:
            llm_pipeline = load_llama_pipeline()
            analysis_df = analyze_student_data(df, llm_pipeline)

            if analysis_df is not None:
                final_df = pd.concat([df.reset_index(drop=True), analysis_df.reset_index(drop=True)], axis=1)

                print("\n--- Full Data with LLM Analysis ---")
                display(final_df)

                print("\n--- Top Performing Students (Average > 80%) ---")
                top_performers = final_df[final_df['is_top_performer'] == True]

                if not top_performers.empty:
                    display(top_performers[['Stud_ID', 'Stud_Fname', 'Stud_Lname', 'total_marks', 'average_percentage']])
                else:
                    print("No students found with an average greater than 80%.")

        except Exception as e:
            print(f"\nAn unexpected error occurred during the analysis process: {e}")
    else:
        print("\nDataFrame is empty. Cannot proceed with analysis.")

8. Example output (simulated for the final cell)

Full Data with LLM Analysis (excerpt)

Stud_ID  Stud_Fname  Stud_Lname  Maths  Physics  Chemistry  total_marks  average_percentage  is_top_performer
101      Arjun       Singh       80     75       80         235          78.33               false
102      Harpreet    Kaur        85     78       85         248          82.67               true
103      Gursimran   Gill        95     85       90         270          90.00               true
104      Manpreet    Sidhu       90     85       95         270          90.00               true
105      Jasleen     Dhillon     89     90       75         254          84.67               true

Top Performing Students (Average > 80%)

Stud_ID  Stud_Fname  Stud_Lname  total_marks  average_percentage
102      Harpreet    Kaur        248          82.67
103      Gursimran   Gill        270          90.00
104      Manpreet    Sidhu       270          90.00
105      Jasleen     Dhillon     254          84.67

 

Part D â€” Production path (same pattern, managed inference)

When performance or scale matters, swap the local pipeline for a hosted endpoint and keep the Datasphere extraction and prompts identical. When performance or scale matters, swap the local pipeline for a hosted endpoint and keep the Datasphere extraction and prompts identical.

1. Databricks Model Serving / Foundation Model Endpoints (REST).
2. Hugging Face Inference Endpoints (private endpoints; REST with your HF token)
3. SAP AI Core (containerized model hosting; REST)SAP AI Core (containerized model hosting; REST)

Minimal REST skeleton --

import requests, os, json
endpoint = os.getenv("INFERENCE_URL")
token = os.getenv("INFERENCE_TOKEN")
r = requests.post(endpoint, headers={"Authorization": f"Bearer {token}"},
                  json={"inputs": "your_prompt_here", "parameters": {"max_new_tokens": 128, "temperature": 0.0}})
print(r.json())



Conclusion ---

This walkthrough demonstrated how to extract data from SAP Datasphere, process it in pandas, and apply a local LLM for row-level analysis that returns clean, machine-readable JSON. The pattern is intentionally small and portable: you can keep iterating locally to refine prompts and outputs, then swap the model call for a managed endpoint (Databricks, Hugging Face, or SAP AI Core) when performance, cost control, or governance call for it. From here, natural next steps include batching larger datasets, persisting results back to a database table, wiring the outputs to SAP Analytics Cloud dashboards, and adding guardrails around data privacy and prompt consistency.

I would be excited to hear how you adapt this to your solutions. Feel free to reach out to me or comment.

entry.title: Re: BKP - Customer Returns Project Solution for Advanced Intercompany Sales
entry.content:
Hi, thanks for post, information is actually useful.

As addition - in one of our project we used LFU 0004 "Move to Other Plant" for 2-steps goods transfer between selling and delivering company + IC credit memo creation. The solution is very similar with option #2, with small differences:

  • Returns STO is used instead of returns PO
  • Inbound + Outbound deliveries are used for IC stock transfer
  • IC Credit memo + invoice verification are created after GR posting for Delivering Company Inbound Delivery.

As result - goods movements and related accounting postings are fully in line with reference sales flow, except SiT postings.

entry.title: Entendiendo la Extensibilidad en SAP Cloud ERP: Parte 2
entry.content:
En el mundo de los sistemas de gestiÃ³n empresarial, la capacidad de extender y personalizar las soluciones es crucial para adaptarse a las necesidades especÃ­ficas de cada negocio o para proveer ventajas competitivas que le permitan diferenciar su negocio. En el primer blog  de esta serie, exploramos las opciones bÃ¡sicas de extensibilidad en SAP Cloud ERP (o comÃºnmente llamado SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition), incluyendo In-App Extensions y Side-by-Side Extensions.

En esta segunda parte, profundizaremos en algunos de los diversos aceleradores o herramientas disponibles dentro de SAP Cloud ERP, como el ejemplo de la BTP Partner Reference App, Joule for Developers, SAP Build, Multi-Off Delivery y Scalable Delivery. AsÃ­ que dÃ©jame llevarte a entender cada una de estas herramientas para potenciar las capacidades de tu compaÃ±Ã­a para crear tu propio IP (Intelectual Property) que es diseÃ±ado con los principios de clean core lo cual lo hace parte de la estrategia de actualizaciÃ³n de la aplicaciÃ³n, es decir no se necesitan adaptaciones durante el upgrade.

 

Aceleradores/Herramientas en In-App Extensibility

1. Joule for Developers

DescripciÃ³n: Joule for Developers permite a los desarrolladores crear extensiones personalizadas dentro del entorno de SAP Cloud ERP. Proporciona un conjunto de herramientas y plantillas que facilitan el proceso de desarrollo. Esta reciente herramienta combina SAP Build Code, SAP Build Process Automation, SAP Build Apps, y el ABAP environment. Esta hecha para acelerar el desarrollo, mejorar la productividad y traer inteligencia dentro de las herramientas que actualmente usas.

entry.title: Step-by-step guide to configure customs declaration in S4HANA with GTS
entry.content:
Majority of SAP customers being global players, most of them are engaged in business which requires export, i.e. selling goods from one country to another.

Today, in this blog we will look at the scenario in which manufacturer from Germany is selling goods to a customer in North America.

Configuration Steps:

We need to configure all the steps in the path SPRO >> IMG >> Transportation Management >> Basic Functions >> Global Trade

  1. Customs Activity:
    • Customs Relevance: Here we define an activity which gets updated based on the Customs relevance check (Step-4). This activity will identify whether the freight order should be marked as relevant for Customs Declaration or not. E.g. when the freight order has country Germany as a source and country Spain as a destination, then the checkbox on the freight order will not be marked as relevant for customs and no customs group will be created as per the European Union agreement.
    • Grouping: We provide a process controller strategy (Step-10) which will create groups. Here we are using SAP provided standard strategy EXP_CONS which will create group based on Consignee.
    • Customs Declaration: Here we choose on which status the declaration should be marked as either relevant or not relevant.
    • Process Status: Here we choose what should be the Customs Process status on the freight order like Requested, Approved or Cancelled.
  2. Customs Profile
    • This is a profile which we have to assign to the Freight Order (Step-9).
    • ASR relevant settings: 

      We have to choose certain check boxes based on what should be the pre-requisites for requesting customs declarations and if we want the steps to be performed automatically on change of freight order status.

      • We select first checkbox if we want the loading to be completed before we request customs declaration
      • Second checkbox is dependent on the first one, and is required if we want Customs Invoice (proforma invoice) to be created before we request custom declaration.
      • Third and fourth checkboxes are for automation of the process, like if we want customs invoice to be created automatically when the right status is available. Similarly the last checkbox is if we want the customs declaration to be sent automatically on appropriate status change.
  3. Assign Activity to Profile

    In this step we have to assign the activity to the profile.

  4. Customs Relevancy Check

    Here we define how the customs relevancy check will be performed. Basically, we have to provide the SE24 class along with the method name in which we have logic to identify the customs relevance. Since our scenario is export from EU, SAP has provided ready to use class, in other cases we have to either write our own class and method by using appropriate interface or it is also possible to achieve this thru BAdI.

  5. Customs Status

    Here we define what all customs statuses we want to see on the freight order.

  6. Cumulated Status

    Here we have to define cumulative statuses and associated block reason if we want to block the Freight Order based on those statuses.



  7. Status Assignment

    Here we assign cumulative statuses to the customs status.



  8. Check Customs Statuses

    This is a report which helps us in identifying if any customs status remains unassigned to cumulative status.

    Result of the report looks like this if everything is defined correctly.



  9. Assign Customs Profile to Freight Order

    The customs profile defined in Step-2 must be assigned to the freight order in this integration settings. If this is not assigned, then the customs relevance check is not performed.



  10. Grouping Strategy

    The grouping strategy must be defined in the process controller (Ref. Step-1b).

Now itâ€™s time to see all these in action.

  1. Create a Sales Order
  2. Plan the freight units associated with the sales order onto a freight order.
  3. Assign carrier, and create delivery. Check customs activity available on the freight order. At this moment, we can see that the customs relevance is not checked.
  4. Set the execution status to â€œReady for Transport Executionâ€. Now we can see that the customs relevance is checked.
  5. Change warehouse execution status to â€œReady for warehouse processingâ€.
  6. Now, we have to perform the relevant steps in EWM like Pick, Pack and mark ready for shipping.
  7. An important configuration on EWM side is required based on business requirements, for when do we want to request customs declaration like before PGI or after PGI. If the highlighted checkbox is marked then we can request customs declaration before performing PGI.
  8. At this point, we can see the customs groups are created, customs invoice is created and customs declaration is sent.
  9. An important configuration is to setup webservice involved in this communication.
    • /SCMTMS/CO_CPX_EXPDECLS_REQ for sending export declaration request from S/4HANA-TM to GTS.
    • /SCMTMS/EXPORTDECLARATIONSUITE is also configured for response message.

  10. Once we receive a response from the Customs Authorities and then from GTS system the freight order is updated with the reference numbers.

The process described above is a basic one. As the custom declaration is a legal requirement, it must be carefully analysed by business and consulting team for the countries involved. As the business grow, the logic may get complex which needs to identify the source/destination and GTS team has to communicate with the right custom office. 

Thanks for reading, appreciate your feedback.

entry.title: AI-Supported Voice-to-Text Job Completion in SAP Service and Asset Manager
entry.content:
Are your technicians tired of slow, error-prone typing after every maintenance job to feed the data demand of your back office? Our new voice-driven AI turns spoken job details into complete confirmation entries â€“ auto-filling hours, expenses, and mileage, hands-free. Cut paperwork, prevent missed information, and help your team close operations faster with cleaner, more reliable data.

In this blog post, weâ€™ll take a closer look at our first productive AI-powered use case implemented for the SAP Service and Asset Manager (SSAM) mobile app. As my colleague @ZackFrazier outlined in his recent post, â€œSAP Service and Asset Manager 2505 Now Available â€“ Whatâ€™s New?â€, we have introduced â€œAI-Supported Voice-to-Text Job Completionâ€ in the latest release, SAP Service and Asset Manager 2505.

Below, we will dive deeper into this AI-Supported Voice-to-Text Job Completion use case from various aspects: functionality, technology, and commercial considerations.

 

See it in action

Check out this video to understand what this feature entails and how it can support your technicians:


 

Whatâ€™s in for you and your technicians?

Let's explore the capabilities and benefits of this feature.

Enhancing Efficiency for Maintenance and Field Technicians

Our inaugural AI-powered feature is designed specifically to boost the efficiency of maintenance and field technicians. It introduces a voice-driven interface that revolutionizes data entry. This cutting-edge feature allows technicians to verbally communicate job details for Work Orders, Service Orders, Operation, or Suboperation directly into the application.

The advanced AI technology then transcribes spoken input into structured data, automatically populating relevant fields such as hours worked, expenses incurred, or mileage traveled. This hands-free approach empowers technicians to capture crucial information promptly and naturally without the inconvenience of manual typing. 

Streamlined Workflow

After the AI accurately fills out the necessary fields, technicians can review and edit the entries if needed. Edits can be made either by verbally re-recording or by selecting and directly updating specific fields using the keyboard. This streamlined workflow accelerates the completion of operations and orders while significantly improving accuracy by minimizing the likelihood of missed or incomplete details.

Boosting Team Efficiency

In essence, this innovative feature contributes to the overall efficiency of the team. By ensuring high-quality data is meticulously maintained, it enhances the team's ability to operate more effectively and efficiently, ultimately leading to a more productive and seamless work environment.

 

How does it work?

Letâ€™s take a closer look at the technology behind this feature.

Technology Stack and Requirements

The spoken information of technicians are transcribed by native speech-to-text cababilities offered by the standard mobile operating system. Technicians must have an online connection as the unstructured text is sent to the SAP AI Core service on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). The large language model gpt 4.1. mini transforms the text into structured data and returns it to SSAM, where it is then entered into the SAP fields on the screen.

To use this new AI feature, you must add the SAP Dynamic Forms service to the entitlements on the BTP subaccount/space where your SAP Service and Asset Manager application is running. However, this prerequisite does not mean you have to use SAP Dynamic Forms actively.

Steps to Set Up the AI Feature

Afterwards you need to go through the following 4 steps:

  • Create the destination required for your mobile application in BTP Mobile Services.
  • Connect the SAP Mobile Service application with SAP Dynamic Forms by configuring the security settings of the SAP Mobile Service application (which links the SAP backend system to the SAP Service and Asset Manager mobile applications). SAP Service and Asset Manager has to be implemented in the same SAP BTP subaccount as SAP Dynamic Forms.
  • Assign users to the role collection which was created by default in step 2 to manage access control.
  • Activate the Application Feature Id â€œCA_AI_JOB_COMPLETIONâ€ in the ConfigPanel of MAIF (Mobile Application Integration Framework).

 

Whatâ€™s the investment to get started?

Regarding commercial aspects, this AI feature follows SAPâ€™s pricing strategy for AI and falls under the premium AI category. It is a consumption-based model where customers need to acquire AI units and are charged per transaction.

Every completion of an operation or order with AI assistance, regardless of how often the end user re-recorded, will count as one transaction. One transaction is equivalent to 0.05 AI units.

You can use the AI estimator tool to calculate your company's needs for AI units.

As this is an AI feature for SAP Service and Asset Manager mobile app, customers will need an active subscription to SAP Service and Asset Manager to use AI within the mobile application.

 

Conclusion

The AI-Supported Voice-to-Text Job Completion feature in SAP Service and Asset Manager is an exciting addition that will significantly boost the productivity of your technicians and your company. It marks the beginning of transforming how end users interact with our mobile app.

I hope you and your technicians will enjoy this new functionality.

For additional information, visit the Discovery center and our SAP Help Portal.

The application metadata is now available for licensed customers and partners on the SAP Support Portal Software Center. Please ensure to download from there the latest patch release of SAP Service and Asset Manager 2505 version. The mobile client can be downloaded from the Apple App Store and Google Play Store.

entry.title: SAP Ariba 2511 Release Key Innovations Preview
entry.content:
Highlights of Enhancements across Procurement

Accelerated Release Cycle for SAP Integration Suite, managed gateway for spend management and SAP Business Network Add-On 1.0 for SAP S/4HANA and SAP ECC (BPI-596)

HEADS-UP! Starting with the SAP Ariba 2602 release, the release frequency of the SAP Integration Suite, managed gateway for spend management, and SAP Business Network 1.0 AddOn increases to four times a year. This applies to SAP S/4 HANA, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, and SAP ECC. The AddOn support package will be released in February, May, August, and November, effective from SAP Ariba release 2602. Increased frequency of delivery provides you with quick access to the latest features, improvements, and compliance enhancements on time, and enables faster adoption.

To benefit from the latest innovations and ensure compliance with support policies, it is recommended that you stay up-to-date by deploying the latest service pack to your production environments.

 

  • This change in release frequency affects the buyer-side add-on, that is SAP Integration Suite, managed gateway for spend management and SAP Business Network Buyer Addon, for SAP ERP and SAP S/4HANA.
  • This change in release frequency does not affect the supplier-side add-on, that is, SAP Integration Suite, managed gateway for spend management and SAP Business Network 1.0 AddOn for SAP ERP Suppliers.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Enhancements to the SAP Ariba SCIM API (MDATA-596)

This feature introduces the following enhancements to the SAP Ariba SCIM API: Support for new fields for the SAP variant (expenseApprovalLimit and approvalLimit), Support for Generic variant fields (ApprovalLimit, ExpenseApprovalLimit, ShipTo, and PurchasingUnit), Support for the following for both variants: Audit logging of user and group changes initiated by the SCIM API, userType option in the $filter parameter, Group Responsible Purchasing Unit (purchasingUnit) field , New name and description attributes to uniquely identify groups.

View implementation details and more here.

 

SAP Ariba Category Management - Highlights 

For further details on these innovations and more, view our blog: SAP Ariba Category Management 2511 Release Key Innovations

 

SAP Ariba Source-to-Contract - Highlights

For further details on these innovations and more, view our blog: SAP Ariba Sourcing & Contracts 2511 Release Key Innovations Preview

 

SAP Ariba Procure-to-Order - Highlights

For further details on these innovations and more, view our blog: SAP Ariba Procure-to-Order 2511 Release Key Innovations

 

SAP Ariba Supplier Management & Risk - Highlights

For further details on these innovations and more, view our blog: SAP Ariba Supplier Management & Risk 2511 Release Key Innovations Preview

 

 

Stay connected with your community for more insights and updates:

  • Register for the Early Release Series for 2511 release- Multi-registration link and for CIM customers- P2P link 
  • Feature related materials:
    • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
    • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
  • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
  • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement  
  • Whatâ€™s New

entry.title: Common troubleshooting steps to identify and resolve issues related to Document Flow in Onboarding
entry.content:
Introduction:

The following article provides guidance on troubleshooting scenarios where the document generation or e-signature step is not being assigned to a candidate.

There can be several reasons why the e-signature step is not assigned to a candidate. In this article, weâ€™ll cover the most common causes of document generation failures and explain how these can be self-resolved.

To start, determine whether the candidateâ€™s e-signature was not triggered due to user validation errors or process validation errors.
Cause 1: User Validation Errors
How to Identify User Validation Failure

  1. Go to BPE: Monitor Processes
  2. Click on Filter
  3. Under Variable add: OnboardingProcessId=<Enter the candidates process id>


Notice the section under â€œActivitiesâ€

If you see the â€œView Document Create Errorsâ€, under Activities, this will indicate that there is a data validation issue with the user (onboardee) who is impacted due to which the Document Flow/E-Signature is not successfully triggered.
Solution 1: Resolve User Validation Errors
In this section, we will show steps on resolving the errors related to User Validation Error
Below is an example of how the error appears' in the Business Process To-Do. The key points to note have been highlighted for your reference in the below screenshot:

As an Error Flow Admin, you can view the specific error details within the Business Process To-Do section. Here are a few self-service steps you can follow to resolve document flow issues based on the error codes:

  • If the status code is 400, this indicates that the form template is invalid/corrupted.
    To correct the issue, go to Maintain Onboarding and Offboarding Document Template, reupload the template and preview it successfully. If you can preview it successfully, you can simply restart the task from the business process to-do.

  • If the status code is 401, this indicates that the issue is with PFS Authentication. Instance is not successfully authenticated with the PFS URL configured.
    To correct this issue, validate if the PFS User Id is associated with the PFS URL or if the PFS URL is associated to the correct company id. Try to login to the PFS URL. If you can successfully login, resave the PFS credentials in Provisioning under Company Settings. If you cannot successfully login, reset the Password associated with the P-User and then login to PFS before saving the credentials in Provisioning.
    If you notice that the PFS URL is incorrectly associated or the P-User is incorrectly associated in provisioning, please feel free to reach out to the Cloud Ops Support via Cloud Ops Portal.

  • If the status code is 403, the issue is with PFS Migration Failure.
    To correct the issue, please create a ticket with SAP Product Support.

  • If the status code is 405, the URL might be configured incorrectly in provisioning.
    To correct the issue, please check the URL configuration in Provisioning under Company Settings. Make sure there are no space or invalid characters.

  • If the status code is 500, this would indicate that there is an issue with the placeholder validation with a specific form. 
    To correct the issue, we need to identify the mapping which has been done between the Custom Form and Candidate Information via placeholders. 
    • Go to Manage Data > Create New > Document Template Mapping Preview.
    • Enter Document Template Mapping Preview ID (Any value can be entered), enter impacted onboardeeâ€™s Process ID and under Document Template enter affected template name (which was shown in BPE error).
    • See which placeholder has unwanted characters such as spaces, tab spaces (\t), or special characters.

      In the above image, as you can see the placeholders â€œRelationship1â€, â€œProportion1â€, â€œGenderâ€ and â€œMaritialStatusâ€ have invalid characters due to which the Document Generation failed with error code 500.
      Note: The above image is not how the results are shown in Document Template Mapping Preview Page. You can use any XML Beautifier to get similar results.

    • Once the placeholders with invalid characters are identified: Go to Maintain Onboarding and Offboarding Document Template, open the mappings for the impacted form and identify the target field
    • If this is mapped to a standard HRIS Elements (Such as Job Information > Business Unit), you can correct the information from Onboarding Dashboard > Actions > New Hire Data
      If this is mapped to a custom MDF Object (Custom Object configured in either New Hire Template or in Additional Data Collection), you can correct the information from Manage Data by searching for the custom object associated with the candidate.
    • After the affected placeholder is corrected, you can restart the Business Process Error from the to-do panel.

  • Status Code 503, this would indicate that the application/document generation service is unavailable due to server issues.

IMPORTANT NOTE: If your instance is migrated from PFS Neo Environment to Cloud Foundry, the error codes are similar to the above explanation.

  • Error code 401 and 405 indicate that there might be an issue with the Service User Authorization during Document Generation.
  • Error code 404 indicates that the templates are not available in the instance.
  • Error code 500 and 503 are the same as explained earlier.

Cause 2: Process Validation Failure
How to Identify Process Validation Failure

  1. Go to BPE: Monitor Processes
  2. Click on Filter
  3. Under Variable add: OnboardingProcessId=<Enter the candidates process id>


Notice the section under â€œJobsâ€:

You can view the error under the â€œJobsâ€ section. This indicates that the Document Generation or E-Signature process failed due to system-level issues such as PFS Server Failure, BPE Server Issues, or instances where BPE was unable to process a backend event, among others.

Solution 2: Resolve Process Validation Errors
In this section, we will show steps on resolving the errors related to Process Validation Error

  1. Go to BPE: Monitor Processes
  2. Click on Filter
  3. Under Variable add: OnboardingProcessId=<Enter the candidates process id>



  4. Copy the Process instance id as highlighted above.
  5. Go to BPE: Manage Process Task
  6. Filter using Process Instance Id and paste the value as copied in step 4
  7. Select the Process Task and click on â€œRestart Taskâ€
  8. If the issue is caused due to intermittent server issues/temporary glitches, the task will be successfully restarted. If this is due to backend issue, you will receive an application error.
  9. If you receive an application error, you can reach out to SAP Product Support

Frequently Asked Questions:

  1. Can we use the same troubleshooting guide if Compliance E-Signature (Country or i9 compliance) is not triggered?
    Answer: Yes, you can follow the same steps. The only difference would be the way you identify the process instance Id in BPE
    i. Go to BPE: Monitor Processes
    ii. Click on Filter
    iii. Under Variable add: userName=<Enter the candidates username>
     
    documents.ComplianceDocumentWorkflow Process Definition Id contains the E-Signature details for compliance tasks.

  2. We are getting Error Code 401 after the instance was refreshed.
    Answer: After the refresh is completed, the PFS credentials are copied from the source instance to the target instance. Due to which the error code 401 is shown. We need to ensure that the target instance is configured with its own PFS credentials.

  3. Do we still have to reset the PFS Password every 6 months?
    Answer: If your instance is already migrated from Neo to Cloud Foundry (CF), there is no need to reset/resave the PFS credentials in Provisioning. This is only applicable to those instances where the migration is incomplete.
     
  4. If the instance is already completed for PFS Migration, what should be the next action?
    Answer: There is no further action required. The complete dependency of the PFS URL will be null after the migration is completed eliminating the need to maintain the credentials in Provisioning or resaving the credentials every 6 months.

  5. We never used PFS before, should we request for a new one now?
    Answer: You should only request for a new URL if your instance is not yet migrated from Neo to CF. Most of the DCs are migrated to CF so please reach out to Cloud Ops support to verify if the migration is completed before requesting for a new one.

entry.title: Solace Agent Mesh ðŸ¤–ðŸŒ : Unlocking Scalable + Real-Time Agentic AI for SAP Customers
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community ðŸ‘‹

I would like to share some hands-on experience with the Solace Agent Mesh and how it could improve the way we build intelligent, event-driven applications in SAP landscapes. If you've been exploring agentic AI, SAP Joule, or event-driven architecture (EDA), this is a framework you need to know about!

I will share some more hands-on tutorials soon.
Feel free to contact me if you have any questions or would like to build with this.

 

ðŸŽ¯What is Solace Agent Mesh?
Solace Agent Mesh is an open-source, event-driven agentic AI framework that enables multiple specialized AI agents to work together seamlessly across your enterprise landscape. Think of it as the nervous system that connects all your intelligent agents, allowing them to communicate, collaborate, and execute complex workflows in real-time.â€‹

I appreciate that it is open source. You can contribute and star â­ï¸ their public repository here:
https://github.com/SolaceLabs/solace-agent-mesh

And learn more on their own website: 
https://solace.com/products/agent-mesh/

To start using the community edition, you can run this in your terminal:

mkdir my-sam && cd my-sam
python3 -m venv .venv && source .venv/bin/activate
pip3 install solace-agent-mesh
sam init --gui
sam run

then go to localhost:8000 to configure the agents and chat with the orchestrator!


Here's what makes it special for SAP customers:

âœ… Event-Driven Foundation â€“ Built on Solace+SAP Advanced Event Mesh, which SAP has partnered with for years to power SAP Event Mesh capabilitiesâ€‹

âœ… Enterprise-Grade Security â€“ Fine-grained access control, delegated permissions, and governance that meets SAP's security standardsâ€‹

âœ… Real-Time Intelligence â€“ Agents react to live business events from SAP S/4HANA, Ariba, SuccessFactors, any third party and moreâ€‹. This extends way beyond database updates; it can include camera video feeds ðŸ“¹, IOT ðŸ›œ, phone calls ðŸ“³, and much more.

âœ… Horizontal Scalability â€“ Asynchronous, decoupled architecture that scales with your businessâ€‹. Agentic AI can truly scale in size and ambition; a network effect appears.

âœ… Multi-Agent Orchestration â€“ Intelligent orchestrator that breaks down complex tasks and delegates them to your specialized agentsâ€‹: github agents do what they do best, salesforce does what they do best, and SAP Joule Agents excel all around your ERP!

 

ðŸ’¡Why SAP Customers Should Care
As SAP professionals, we're living in an exciting time where agentic AI is transforming enterprise operations. SAP Joule is already showing us what's possible with AI agents in finance, procurement, supply chain, and HR. But here's the challenge: How do you connect these agents to real-time data across your entire IT landscape?â€‹

This is where Solace Agent Mesh becomes invaluable:

ðŸ”— Seamless SAP Integration â€“ Direct integration with SAP S/4HANA via SAP Integration Suite, enabling real-time event consumption from your SAP systemsâ€‹

âš¡ Event-Driven by Design â€“ Leverages SAP's event-driven architecture principles, working perfectly with SAP Event Mesh and SAP BTPâ€‹

ðŸ¤– Complements SAP Joule â€“ While Joule provides AI copilot capabilities within SAP applications, Solace Agent Mesh extends agentic intelligence across your entire multi-system landscapeâ€‹

ðŸŒ Hybrid Cloud Ready â€“ Works across on-premise SAP ECC, S/4HANA Cloud, and third-party applications like Salesforce, Oracle, and custom systemsâ€‹

 

ðŸŽ¬Real-World Scenario: Intelligent Request for Quote (RFQ) Processing
Let me walk you through a powerful use case that showcases the magic of combining Solace Agent Mesh with SAP systems: Automated, Multi-System RFQ Processing.

The Business Challenge ðŸ¤”
Imagine you're a manufacturing company. A customer submits an RFQ by mail for 10,000 custom electronic components. To respond with an accurate, competitive quote, your team needs to:

Understand customer requirements (from Salesforce CRM)

Check product specifications (from SAP S/4HANA Product Catalog)

Verify current inventory (from SAP S/4HANA MM)

Assess production capacity (from real-time manufacturing systems/IoT)

Evaluate supplier pricing (from SAP Ariba)

Calculate optimal pricing (considering market conditions, customer history, margins)

Generate compliant quote (meeting regulatory and business rules)

Traditionally, this takes 3-5 days with multiple people manually gathering data from different systems, countless emails, and spreadsheet gymnastics ðŸ“ŠðŸ˜…. With Solace Agent Mesh, this can happen in seconds âš¡.

The Solution Architecture ðŸ—ï¸
Here's how an event-driven multi-agent system would work:

1 - An incoming message of any nature becomes an event

2 - The Solace Orchestrator understands the situation and dispatches work to various other agents.

3 - Those agents are called through A2A, communication happens through events, topics, etc.

4 - The human sales team can oversee this process, and approve or modify the final quote.

5 - A high-quality, real-time answer can be quickly provided to the customer!

The Agent Team ðŸ¤–ðŸ¤
Let's meet the specialized agents working together:

1ï¸âƒ£ Customer Intelligence Agent (Salesforce Integration)
Skills: Retrieves customer history, preferences, contract terms from Salesforce

Data: Past orders, payment history, negotiated discounts, relationship tier

Value: Ensures pricing aligns with customer agreements and maximizes conversion

2ï¸âƒ£ Product Catalog Agent (SAP S/4HANA Integration)
Skills: Validates product codes, retrieves specifications, BOM data

Data: Technical specs, material master data, alternative products

Value: Ensures technical feasibility and suggests alternatives if neededâ€‹

3ï¸âƒ£ Inventory Agent (SAP S/4HANA MM)
Skills: Real-time inventory checks, lead time calculations

Data: Current stock levels, reserved quantities, warehouse locations

Value: Provides accurate delivery timelinesâ€‹

4ï¸âƒ£ Production Capacity Agent (Manufacturing Systems/MES)
Skills: Analyzes real-time production schedules and machine availability

Data: Current production runs, machine uptime, capacity forecasts

Value: Validates if order can be fulfilled in requested timeframeâ€‹

5ï¸âƒ£ Supplier Evaluation Agent (SAP Ariba)
Skills: Assesses supplier pricing, quality ratings, delivery performance

Data: Supplier catalogs, negotiated rates, risk scores

Value: Optimizes make-vs-buy decisions and supplier selectionâ€‹

6ï¸âƒ£ Pricing Optimization Agent (Multi-Source)
Skills: Calculates optimal pricing considering costs, margins, competition

Data: Raw material costs, labor rates, overhead, market pricing, customer willingness-to-pay

Value: Maximizes profitability while remaining competitiveâ€‹

7ï¸âƒ£ Quote Generation Agent (Orchestrator)
Skills: Aggregates all inputs, applies business rules, generates formatted quote

Data: Compiled data from all agents, compliance requirements, approval thresholds

Value: Produces compliant, accurate quote ready for customer deliveryâ€‹


Why This Architecture Wins ðŸ†
ðŸš€Speed: What took 3-5 days now takes minutes

âœ…Accuracy: Real-time data from source systems eliminates manual errors and outdated informationâ€‹

ðŸ’°Cost Efficiency: Agents manage data intelligently; only relevant information sent to LLMs, reducing token costsâ€‹

ðŸ”’Security: Fine-grained access control ensures agents only access data they're authorized forâ€‹

ðŸ“ˆScalability: Handle thousands of RFQs simultaneously without adding headcountâ€‹

ðŸ”„Adaptability: Add new agents (e.g., sustainability scoring, compliance checking) without disrupting existing workflowsâ€‹

ðŸŒMulti-System: Seamlessly orchestrates SAP, Salesforce, manufacturing systems, and external data sourcesâ€‹

 

ðŸ”§Technical Integration with SAP
For the SAP technical integration, here's how you'd integrate this:

SAP S/4HANA Integration

# Example SAC configuration for SAP S/4HANA agent agent: name: "ProductCatalogAgent" type: "adk" connections: - name: "S4HANA_Connection" type: "odata" url: "${S4HANA_ODATA_URL}" auth: type: "oauth2" token_url: "${S4HANA_TOKEN_URL}" tools: - name: "GetProductDetails" description: "Retrieve product specifications from SAP S/4HANA" api_endpoint: "/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_PRODUCT_SRV"


SAP Event Mesh Integration

# Event Mesh configuration for event-driven triggers event_broker: type: "solace" connection: host: "${SAP_EVENT_MESH_HOST}" vpn: "${SAP_EVENT_MESH_VPN}" auth: type: "oauth" subscriptions: - topic: "sap/s4hana/product/changed" - topic: "sap/ariba/supplier/updated" - topic: "salesforce/opportunity/created"

SAP Integration Suite Connection
You can use the Solace Micro-Integration for SAP Integration Suite to connect your agents to SAP Event Mesh. This allows:â€‹
- Consuming events from SAP S/4HANA business eventsâ€‹
- Publishing agent results back to SAP systemsâ€‹
- Supporting both guaranteed (persistent) and direct messagingâ€‹

 

ðŸŽ¯Benefits Beyond RFQ Processing
The Solace Agent Mesh architecture isn't limited to RFQs. SAP customers can apply this pattern to:

ðŸ“¦ Supply Chain Orchestration â€“ Agents monitor inventory levels, predict stockouts, automatically trigger purchase requisitions in SAP Aribaâ€‹

ðŸ’° Accounts Payable Automation â€“ Invoice matching agents reconcile POs, goods receipts, and invoices across SAP FI, SAP MM, and supplier portalsâ€‹

ðŸ­ Predictive Maintenance â€“ IoT agents detect equipment anomalies, automatically create maintenance orders in SAP S/4HANA, schedule technicians from SuccessFactorsâ€‹

ðŸ‘¥ Employee Onboarding â€“ HR agents coordinate document collection, account creation, training schedules across SuccessFactors, Active Directory, and learning systemsâ€‹

ðŸ›’ Order-to-Cash Optimization â€“ Sales agents validate orders against contracts, check credit limits, optimize delivery schedules across SAP SD, SAP FI, and logistics systemsâ€‹

 

ðŸš€Getting Started
Ready to explore Solace Agent Mesh for your SAP landscape? Here's how to begin:

1ï¸âƒ£ Start Small â€“ Pick one high-volume, repetitive process (like RFQ or invoice matching) that involves SAP and non-SAP. systems

2ï¸âƒ£ Identify Your Agents â€“ Map out which systems need to be queried and what data is needed

3ï¸âƒ£ Set Up Event Mesh â€“ Configure SAP Event Mesh or Solace PubSub+ to connect your systemsâ€‹

4ï¸âƒ£ Build Your First Agent â€“ Use the Solace Agent Mesh framework to create a simple agent that queries SAP S/4HANAâ€‹

5ï¸âƒ£ Add Orchestration â€“ Deploy the orchestrator to coordinate multiple agentsâ€‹

6ï¸âƒ£ Scale Gradually â€“ Add more agents and complexity as you gain confidence

 

Resources ðŸ“š
Solace Agent Mesh GitHub: github.com/SolaceLabs/solace-agent-meshâ€‹

SAP Integration Suite Documentation: Connect SAP systems to Solace Event Meshâ€‹

Solace Codelabs: Getting started tutorialsâ€‹

SAP BTP Event-Driven Architecture Reference: Best practices for EDA on SAP BTPâ€‹

 

ðŸŽ¬Conclusion
The future of SAP is event-driven and agentic ðŸ¤–âš¡.


By combining SAP's powerful business applications with Solace Agent Mesh's intelligent orchestration, we can build systems that:

- React in real-time to business events

- Make intelligent decisions across multiple systems

- Scale effortlessly as your business grows

- Maintain enterprise-grade security and governance

Whether you're working with SAP S/4HANA, SAP Ariba, SAP SuccessFactors, or integrating with Salesforce, Oracle, and custom systems, Solace Agent Mesh provides the event-driven backbone to make your agentic AI vision a reality.

I'd love to hear your thoughts! Have you experimented with event-driven architectures or agentic AI in your SAP landscape? What use cases are you most excited about?

Happy coding, and may your events always flow smoothly! ðŸš€âœ¨

entry.title: Re: Creation of OBD automatically for the Subcon PO
entry.content:
Hi, 

In SAP, there is no standard automatic process that creates an Outbound Delivery (OBD) immediately upon Subcontracting Purchase Order (PO) or Scheduling Agreement (SA) creation.

  • Subcontracting PO/SA Creation
    • When you create a subcontracting PO (item category â€˜Lâ€™), SAP expects that you will manually provide the components to the subcontracting supplier.
    • The system records the component requirement (via BOM explosion) but does not automatically create an Outbound Delivery at that moment.
  • Component Provision to Subcontractor
    • The standard process is:
      • Create PO (ME21N / ME31L)
      • Check subcontracting stock requirements (via ME2O)
      • Manually create Outbound Delivery (VL10B or ME2O â†’ Create Delivery)
      • Post goods issue (VL02N)

So, standard SAP does not automatically trigger OBD creation at PO/SA creation.

You may create your own enhancement, but it will be a bit challenging as you have to take care of stock as well as inventory and same time inventory valuation as well. 

Thanks
Santosh

entry.title: Re: Looking for Documentation on ADT (ABAP Development To...
entry.content:
Hi Rosario,

A few months back I started a personal project of building a proper language server for ABAP which put me in a similar place as you are in now, specifically regarding trying to figure out the inner workings of ADT.

The first clue is the ABAP-FS Extension for vscode that already exists, you can find the source code on github. Unfortunately, that also is based on a ton of "guesses" and has zero to none documentation, hence why I started working on my own language server rather than improving on the existing implementation.

As per the reply you already got, some official documentation does exist. Unfortunately, what is documented is their internal Eclipse API for Extension developers - not the ADT API itself. To me it was essentially useless.

A few things that may help you, if you havent already found them yourself:
- You can enable the ABAP Communication Log in Eclipse to track the requests being made
- You can use the /sap/bc/adt/development/handler/adtresource?uri=<uri> endpoint to find the handlers
- What helped me the most: Read the ABAP source code of the handlers

Regarding stateless/stateful sessions and some more, you can refer to some resources I wrote up here initially:
https://github.com/kennyhml/abap-language-server/tree/master/lib/adt-query

I also have the virtual filesystem and some other stuff largely implemented, you can refer to that documentation for my insights as well. Currently my focus is on the language server part of the project, not the ADT client, but itll probably prove useful anyway.

If you got any questions or want to talk about it feel free to reach out

entry.title: Integration of SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere using JDBC
entry.content:
Integration Between SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere (JDBC Connection)  
 
JDBC â€“ JAVA DATABASE CONNECTIVITY 
 
Why Recommendation for JDBC Over OData API : 
JDBC is recommended over OData when consuming large-scale records (e.g., 100,000+) because JDBC streams data directly from the database with better performance and less overhead, while OData is optimized for lightweight, paginated, service-based access. 
 
Problem statement: 3337495 - OData API returns less records than expected due paging 
Pagination limits in OData and Ariba APIs can be handled in SAP CPI using a looping process call. 
 
Goal: Connect CPI to a database used by DataSphere (JDBC) and run a simple read data from the (Analytical Model / Table /View).  
 
For the Write / Delete / Update method, the attached SAP Help Portal Link has syntax in the reference section. 
 
Prerequisites: 

  1. SAP DataSphere â€“ Subscribed account (âš  Trial has limited features, JDBC not supported) 
  1. SAP Integration Suite â€“ Subscribed or Trial (JDBC actions supported) 

 

SAP DataSphere Step by Step Guide : 
 

Step 

Action / Notes 

1. Create a Space 

DataSphere â†’ Space Management â†’ New Space â†’ Name it â†’ Create. 

2. Create Table / Analytical Model 

Data Builder â†’ In your Space â†’ New â†’ Table or Analytical Model â†’ define fields & data types â†’ Save & Publish. 
*Verify Table/Model Deployed Successfully. * 

3. Prepare / Load Data 

Load data manually for testing cases. Otherwise load CSV/import to table via Data Builder/Data Integration. 

4. Note Schema & Object Names 

Record schema name, table name, and view names for JDBC SQL use. 
* Created space name is the SCHEMA name and Collect Table / Model name * 

5. Decide Where to Create DB User 

If HANA Cloud â†’ use HANA Cockpit/DB Explorer. If on-prem DB â†’ use DB admin tools or contact DB Admin. 
* We are using the HANA cloud system for practical session* 

6. Create JDBC DB User 

DB admin tool â†’ Security/Users â†’ New User â†’ set username & strong password â†’ Save. 
*Check Active status of User* 

7. Grant Privileges for the DB user 

Assign only required privileges (e.g., SELECT for read; add INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE for CRUD). Best practice: create role JDBC_ROLE and assign. 

8. Prepare JDBC Connection Details 

Gather JDBC URL (e.g.  sample URL from datasphere: z*********-abc.hana.prod-eu10.hanacloud.ondemand.com 
Format for CPI JDBC Material: 
jdbc:sap://<host>:<port>/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true 

 
SAP Integration Suite Step by Step Guide : 
 
Create a Package & Artifact 

  • In CPI â†’ Design â†’ Create a new package â†’ Add an integration flow artifact. 
  • âœ… Make sure your CPI user has the required roles to create and access design-time artifacts. 
     

Go to Monitoring â†’ JDBC Material 

  • In CPI â†’ Monitor â†’ Integrations and APIs â†’ Manage Security â†’ JDBC Material

     

     
  • â†’ Add JDBC Data Source. â†’ Select HANA cloud  

     

     
     
  • Provide JDBC URL in the correct format (e.g., jdbc:sap://<hana-host>:443/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true). 

     

     
  • Enter DB username and password (use the dedicated JDBC user created earlier in DataSphere). 

     

     
  • Save and deploy the JDBC material. 
    •  

    Apply JDBC Material in iFlow

    • In your integration flow, configure the JDBC receiver adapter â†’ select the JDBC data source created.
    • Use SQL queries (SELECT) in the Processing tab or provide XML query body. Here, Iâ€™m using SQL SELECT * to fetch all records from the table.

     


    Step 1: Timer Start
     In this iFlow, the Start Timer is configured with a Simple Schedule â†’ None â†’ On Deployment, which means the integration flow automatically triggers immediately after deployment.

     


    Step 2: Content Modifier
    Use this SQL query to fetch all records with the body operation.
     SELECT * FROM "<Schema>"."<Model/TableName>"

     



    Step 3: Request Reply & JDBC Receiver Adapter
         â†’ Use the deployed JDBC Data Source alias in the JDBC Material in the previous step and set Max records count based on your requirement.
    â†’ JDBC Maximum Records per call:  2,147,483,647

     


    Sample data Response from JDBC Connection:

     



    References :

    CPI JDBC â€“ XML Query in Body for CRUD Operations (Syntax Guide)
     link:
    https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/payload-and-operation

entry.title: Re: Beginners Guide to Advanced Event Mesh
entry.content:
Hi,

Iâ€™ve also been running some tests with AEM and CPI, and Iâ€™m having trouble achieving EO (Exactly Once) behavior with scheduled resends (e.g., after one hour).

When a message fails, it gets stuck and blocks the corresponding node consumer. Eventually, after several failures, all CPI consumers end up blocked by failed messages.

As a result, no new messages are consumed until those failed ones are rejectedâ€”usually hours later, depending on the CPI sender adapterâ€™s redelivery configuration.

What configuration or combination of queue and adapter would you recommend to avoid this blocking behavior while still keeping the redelivery settings active in CPI?

Thanks in advance

entry.title: Step-by-Step Guide to Enabling the HTML5 Applications Repository in SAP BTP
entry.content:
This Blog explain the how to enable the HTML5 Applications repository

At first we need to enable the 2 things successfully like 

1. Cloud Identity Services

2. SAP Build Work Zone

In the very first step is to click the Create option in your Instances and Subscriptions tab

In this New Instance Window click on Cloud Identity Services then Plan will be default

Service: Cloud Identity Services

Plan: default

Once you done click on Create in the Bottom of the Screen

Once you have create the above service successfully then we need to move on to the Users tab then click on user we need and click on Assign Role Collection

Once you click on that the Assign Role Collection Dialogue will open then we need to search and assign the roles in below

Cloud Connector Administrator, Connectivity and Destination Administrator, Subaccount Service Administrator, Subaccount Viewer

Once you have assigned the role it will looks like below

After completing the above step, please check your email for a message regarding identity authentication. Click the link provided in the email to activate it and verify your account.

 

 

Once you click on the link the Cloud Identity service will open if not just go the Cloud Identity service which was in your BTP Instance and service

 

 

Once you have verified through mail move to the Instances and Subscriptions tab click on Cloud Identity then click Go to Application

 

Once you have done you will see this page Cloud Identity Services in this click on User Management

After clicking the User Management verify the user credentials here

Then move on the Trust Configuration Part under the Security then click on Establish Trust the configure Tenant pop up will open

In this select the Default value 

In this choose Domain option choose option end with â€˜trail-accound.ondemand.comâ€™

Then click on create to sap build work zone

With this you can go for standard subscription plan

We have successfully activated the sap Build work zone

 

Then will check on HTML5 Applications tab you can see HTML5 application now allow to add application here, Thank for Reading!

entry.title: Creating custom events in SAP Event Mesh
entry.content:
Hello,

In this step-by-step guide, I would like to show how to create a custom event in SAP to make an availability filter events.

For this guide, I will presenta  solution for event raised during the creation of the document material

1. Make a function module (for now, w/o logic)

2. Make a reference in business objects

Go to the SWE2 transaction and make a new configuration like below:

3. Open Eclipse and create the following objects:

1. View Entity:

2. Abstract Entity:

3. Behaviour definition

4. Create a class for behaviour definition: you will get a prompt in the first line about missing implementation

5. Event Binding

4. After activating all of the objects from point 3, you can go back to the function module from point 1 and add the logic

5. Go to transaction /IWXBE/CONFIG to make a configuration for the newly created channel

You can check that in SE38 by executing report /IWXBE/R_EVENT_MONITOR

entry.title: Re: Possibility of Restricting Access to Specific Billing...
entry.content:
Dear customer, you can use app authorization variants (a type of IAM app) to fulfill this business requirement.

This concept enables you to assign authorizations to individual users on a per-app level. So you can build roles that, for example, only contain authorizations for the Create Billing Documents and Display Billing Documents apps, and another role specifically for the Manage Billing Documents and Change Billing Documents app.

For more information, see https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/53e36b5493804bcdb3f6f14de8b487dd/e2b39fb01689420393931a9eb3f627ec.html?version=2508.500

entry.title: Read more on Confirmed' or 'Confirmed Automatically cases and what can be done?
entry.content:
Here is all you need to know if a case is confirmed or confirmed automatically, and you still need support from SAP 

What does Confirmed and Automatically Confirmed mean?  

Confirmed â€” The case was closed by the customer and can no longer be reopened. The case can be found in the Closed Cases section of the case list.   

If a case is â€˜confirmed automaticallyâ€™ it means that case was in one of the below statuses for over 21 days with no response from the customer and can no longer be reopened.   

  • Customer Action  
  • SAP Proposed Solution  

Read more on this here SAP Knowledge Base Article (KBA) 1929454â€¯- What is the time for the automatic closure of supportâ€¯cases and 2537073 - What is the time for automatic closure of support  

 A case that is 'Confirmed' or 'Confirmed Automaticallyâ€™ cannot be reopened however what can be done with a valid S-user ID within the organization and has the correct authorizations is create A New Case - About the User, Authorization, and Administrator Concept   

When creating the new case ( 1296527 - How to create a support case for SAP Support - SAP for Me) when filling out the  Description ensure to mention the previous case number that is confirmed.   

 

The relevant team will then know that the new case is related to a previous one that is confirmed, and the new case will be picked up from where the previous case was processed.

We suggest that if SAP has requested information on the confirmed case, you should include the reply in the new case to ensure the most efficient support.  

Thanks for reading!â€¯ â€¯â€¯  

We hope you found this useful.

Please note that theâ€¯Customer Interaction Centerâ€¯is always happy to guide you on any of the mentioned processes and assist you with any queries youâ€¯may have.â€¯â€¯  

If you have any questions, please ask a question in the Q & A usingâ€¯All Questions in Customer Experience | SAP Communityâ€¯andâ€¯All Questions in Support Services | SAP Communityâ€¯  

Read more #CustomerInteractionCenterâ€¯blogposts "CustomerInteractionCenter" - SAP Community â€¯
